|Title=Know the definition, significance and aetiological approach to transient monocular blindness
|Description=None
|Rubric=Definition
|Contributors=
|Order=2}}
Amaurosis fugax is an acute onset of total visual loss lasting a few minutes and resolving spontaneously. It corresponds to a ''transient ischaemic attack of the retina''.

It is a diagnostic ''emergency'' because of the risk of a ''constituted retinal artery occlusion or ischaemic stroke''.

Carotid atheroma or embolism cardiopathy should be sought first. Horton's disease should also be systematically considered.

properties.question: What is the correct definition of transient monocular blindness?
properties.option_a: A permanent loss of vision in one eye due to retinal damage.
properties.option_b: An acute onset of total visual loss in one eye lasting a few minutes, resolving spontaneously, often indicating a potential retinal artery occlusion or stroke.
properties.option_c: A chronic condition causing gradual vision loss in both eyes, commonly linked to glaucoma.
properties.option_d: A temporary decrease in vision quality in one eye due to refractive errors, such as nearsightedness or astigmatism.
